DOC.HEAD: $adv22
For Release Friday AMs, Dec. 22, and thereafter
DOC.TEXT: The first Roman Catholic Mass from the Soviet Union to be telecast in the United States will be carried Christmas Eve by the Vision Interfaith Satellite Network. Jeff Weber, program vice president for the cable system, said the service from Vilnius Cathedral in Lithuania would be presented at 9 p.m. EST on Sunday, and repeated Christmas Day at 5 p.m. The Mass is to be celebrated by Archbishop Julionas Steponovicius of Vilnius, believed to have been secretly made a cardinal by Pope John Paul II in 1979. He was allowed to resume his church duties only a year ago. The 14th century Vilnius Cathedral, known as the ``cradle of Lithuanian Christianity,'' was seized by Soviet authorities in the 1950s and converted into a secular gallery, but was returned to the church early this year. VISN is operated by a consortium of 22 faith groups in the Eastern Orthodox, Jewish, Roman Catholic and Protestant religions.

The policy-making general board of the American Baptist Churches has urged the federal government to re-establish full diplomatic relations with Cuba and to lift the trade embargo on the country. The board also urged a halt to U.S. military aid to El Salvador.

Amid the injustices in the world and wasteful exploitation of nature, the World Council of Churches general secretary says Christmas raises a beacon of hope. The Rev. Emilio Castro said in a holiday message: ``God in Christ has established forever a token of encouragement to which all can turn who hunger and thirst for justice, a promise of peace for all those who are peacemakers, and ... an objective vision of all who struggle for justice, peace and the integrity of creation.''

Randall A. Terry of Binghamton, N.Y., who founded the ``Operation Rescue'' anti-abortion movement, has been honored by Christian Herald magazine with its annual ``James 1:22 Award'' as a leading ``doer of the Word'' in 1989. His ``controversial and dramatic tactics have forced Christians to either join the fight over abortion or turn their backs on the babies and mothers,'' said Bob Cuivala, editor of the 113-year-old evangelical magazine.

The Soviet Union is sponsoring its first conference on Jewish history in more than 40 years, says one of the participants, Rabbi Ishmar Schorsch, chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America. ``We are afforded a unique opportunity to facilitate a Jewish renaissance in the Soviet Union,'' he said of the conference, which will be Dec. 25-27 in Moscow.

Roman Catholic Archbishop Rembert Weakland said he will hold hearings to gather women's views on abortion. He wrote in the Milwaukee archdiocese's newspaper, Catholic Herald, that he hoped ``a more systematic hearing and listening process ... will help me understand and articulate better my own moral insights'' on abortion.

People have an extra reason for celebrating Christmas this year _ the end of the Cold War between West and East, says the president of the United Methodist Council of Bishops. Declaring the year has seen the ``unfolding of events in the family of nations which hold the promise of a truly better day for humankind,'' Bishop Jack Tuell of Los Angeles said in a Christmas message: ``Long-standing repressive regimes have yielded to the cries of the people for a fuller measure of the freedom and dignity with which God has endowed all of humanity. ``Groups long separated by artificail political barriers now are coming together to form new relationships of community and cooperation. The God who is the God of peace and justice and freedom is surely at work in all this.''
